title: ESXi Escape: Chinese APT Exploits VMware Zero-Days for Hypervisor Takeover (CISA KEV)
affected_products: All virtualized infrastructure using affected versions

timeline.event: Earliest exploit artifacts discovered with XLab references, suggesting modular development
PDB debug symbols indicate exploit development began in Chinese-speaking environment
Broadcom discloses zero-days reported by Microsoft Threat Intelligence Center
CISA adds all three CVEs to Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
Huntress observes active exploitation via SonicWall VPN compromise
Shadowserver reports 30,000+ internet-exposed vulnerable ESXi instances
Huntress publishes detailed analysis linking exploitation to Chinese-speaking threat actors

simple_summary.what_happened: Three critical zero-day vulnerabilities in VMware ESXi allow attackers to escape from a virtual machine and take complete control of the underlying hypervisor. Chinese-linked threat actors developed exploit tools over a year before public disclosure and have been actively using them in sophisticated attacks. The exploit chain enables VM-to-hypervisor escape, giving attackers control over all virtual machines on the host.
simple_summary.who_is_affected: Any organization running VMware ESXi, Workstation, or Fusion is at risk. Over 30,000 internet-exposed ESXi instances were identified as vulnerable as of January 2026. The threat group UNC3886 has primarily targeted defense, technology, and telecommunications organizations in the US and Asia-Pacific regions. Cloud service providers and enterprises with large virtualized infrastructure are high-value targets.
simple_summary.what_attackers_do: Step 1: Initial access typically via compromised VPN appliance (SonicWall observed). Step 2: Lateral movement to gain Domain Admin access and reach VM infrastructure. Step 3: Deploy MAESTRO orchestrator toolkit inside a compromised VM. Step 4: Exploit CVE-2025-22226 to leak VMX memory and bypass ASLR. Step 5: Chain CVE-2025-22224 (TOCTOU) to execute code as VMX process. Step 6: Use CVE-2025-22225 to escape VMX sandbox and write to ESXi kernel. Step 7: Deploy VSOCKpuppet backdoor for persistent hypervisor access. Step 8: Control all VMs on the hypervisor, exfiltrate data, or deploy ransomware.
what_you_should_do: Immediately patch all VMware ESXi instances to the latest fixed versions
Audit and secure VPN appliances - SonicWall was used for initial access
Monitor for VSOCK processes using network utilities (indicates backdoor)
Check for suspicious kernel drivers that should not be present
Review Domain Admin account activity for lateral movement indicators
Retire end-of-life ESXi versions that receive no security updates
Implement network segmentation to limit hypervisor exposure
simple_summary.why_this_is_serious: VM escape is one of the most impactful vulnerabilities in virtualized environments - it breaks the fundamental isolation guarantee between virtual machines. A single compromised VM can now compromise the hypervisor and ALL other VMs running on it. The exploit toolkit was developed by well-resourced Chinese-speaking threat actors over a year before disclosure, suggesting sophisticated state-sponsored activity. With 30,000+ exposed instances and active exploitation, organizations must patch immediately.

tactics.description: Compromising VPN appliances (SonicWall) for initial network access
Exploiting VM escape vulnerabilities to gain hypervisor-level access
Deploying kernel-level backdoors on ESXi hypervisor
Installing VSOCKpuppet backdoor for persistent hypervisor access

tactics.technique_name: Use Alternate Authentication Material: Application Access Token
tactics.description: Using hypervisor access to control all guest VMs
Accessing memory and data from all VMs on compromised hypervisor

detection_guidance.summary: Monitor for unusual VMCI driver activity, VSOCK-based communications, and suspicious kernel module loading on ESXi hosts. Focus on detecting lateral movement from guest VMs to hypervisor and unexpected network connections from ESXi management interfaces.

log_sources.description: VMkernel logs, authentication logs, and module loading events
VM operations, administrative actions, and configuration changes
Authentication events and unusual access patterns
Domain Admin account usage and lateral movement indicators
VSOCK communications and unusual ESXi management traffic

what_to_look_for.description: Unusual VSOCK-based network connections from ESXi host
what_to_look_for.log_field: Network connections using AF_VSOCK socket family

what_to_look_for.description: Loading of kernel modules not signed by VMware
what_to_look_for.log_field: VMkernel module load events with unknown signatures

what_to_look_for.description: Disabling or manipulation of VMCI drivers
VPN logins from unusual locations or at unusual times
what_to_look_for.log_field: VPN authentication events with geographic anomalies

what_to_look_for.description: Domain Admin accounts accessing VM infrastructure
what_to_look_for.log_field: AD authentication events for privileged accounts on ESXi/vCenter

immediate_actions.description: Identify all ESXi hosts and their current patch levels
Update to patched versions: ESXi 8.0 Update 3d, ESXi 7.0 Update 3r, or later
Look for suspicious VSOCK processes on ESXi hosts
immediate_actions.command: esxcli network ip connection list | grep -i vsock

immediate_actions.description: Check for unsigned or suspicious kernel modules
Audit VPN appliance logs for unauthorized access attempts
Ensure ESXi management interfaces are not exposed to internet
